Question_1.Context: The study aimed to assess if organic matter load exceeding a certain threshold could artificially produce BPCA during black carbon analysis.
Question_1.Question: What was the maximum total organic carbon (TOC) load in soil samples where no artificial BPCA formation occurred?
Question_1.Source: Our results show that for soil samples, no artificial BPCA formation occurred at least up to 20 mg of total organic carbon.

Question_2.Context: The study analyzed different plant materials to investigate the artificial formation of BPCA during oxidation processes.
Question_2.Question: Which plant material showed artificial BPCA formation when more than 10 mg of total organic carbon (TOC) was used?
Question_2.Source: In Beech leaves, only B3CA was produced when TOC load exceeded 10 mg.

Question_3.Context: The study compared the results of conventional high-pressure digestion with microwave-assisted oxidation process.
Question_3.Question: Which method showed a significantly higher B3CA content in Ivy and Thuja samples?
Question_3.Source: A significantly higher B3CA content in the Ivy and Thuja samples treated with microwave-assisted oxidation process compared to the conventional method was observed.

Question_4.Context: The study investigated the correlation between black carbon content and sample weight as mg of TOC in plant samples.
Question_4.Question: Which plant sample showed a significantly higher black carbon content in the high-pressure oxidation process compared to the microwave-assisted process?
Question_4.Source: In Beech leaves, there was a significantly higher black carbon content of 4.69 g kg−1 in the high-pressure oxidation process compared to the microwave-assisted process.

Question_5.Context: The study analyzed the individual benzenepolycarboxylic acids and black carbon content in plant samples.
Question_5.Question: Which plant material showed an increase in B4CA content from 0.2 to 0.7 g kg−1?
Question_5.Source: The mean content of B4CA increased from 0.2 to 0.7 g kg−1 in Thuja samples.

Question_6.Context: The study assessed the correlation between B6CA content and sample weight as mg of TOC in plant samples.
Question_6.Question: Which plant sample showed artificial formation of B6CA only when more than 200 mg of TOC was oxidized?
Question_6.Source: B6CA was detected only in Ivy leaves when more than 200 mg of TOC was oxidized.

Question_7.Context: The study compared the results of conventional and microwave-assisted oxidation processes.
Question_7.Question: Which method showed a significantly higher B5CA content in Beech leaves?
Question_7.Source: B4CA and B5CA showed significantly higher contents in Beech leaves in the microwave-assisted oxidation process compared to the high-pressure digestion.

Question_8.Context: The study investigated the correlation between sample weight as mg of TOC and BPCA content in plant samples.
Question_8.Question: Which plant sample showed a positive correlation between B3CA content and lignin content?
Question_8.Source: B3CA showed a positive correlation with lignin content in Thuja needles.

Question_9.Context: The study compared the results of conventional and microwave-assisted oxidation processes.
Question_9.Question: Which method showed no significant differences in black carbon content in Ivy, Spruce, and Thuja samples?
Question_9.Source: The black carbon content was not significantly different among the two oxidation methods in Ivy, Spruce, and Thuja samples.

Question_10.Context: The study assessed the artificial formation of BPCA during oxidation processes.
Question_10.Question: What was the maximum total organic carbon (TOC) load in plant samples where no artificial BPCA formation occurred?
Question_10.Source: No artificial formation of BPCA occurred when the TOC load was lower than 28 mg in Ivy leaves, 12 mg in Spruce leaves/needles, 12 mg in Thuja leaves/needles.
